text: Classic bitter aroma. Pretty in the glass with that creamy white head and perfectly still golden body. Very smooth and refreshing to start, before bitter notes and sweeter ones fight it out. Creamy finish with a lingering bitterness. Quite impressive and up there with the best bitters Ive had.

Pulled not poured. Golden yellow with little carbonation. Creamy mouthfeel. Earthy 

---Rated via Beer Buddy

Cask, Mariners Great Yarmouth. 
Golden amber appearance with fast fading thin white head. Aroma of biscuit, bread and malts. Taste of biscuit, some light citrus flavours with a slightly bitter aftertaste. Its okay, drinkable but nothing remarkable.

From many pubs over many years. This is one of the UKs great cask beers, and its good enough that Ill often choose a pint of it over an un-rated cask beer when Im in a pub. It stays true to style, with a light sweetness, moderate bitterness, and a gentle mouthfeel, but the combination of the "toast and biscuits" flavor from the Golden Promise malt and the Styrian Golding hops elevate this to a world-class level Bitter. Excellent stuff.
Ljust bärnstensfärgad med ett rikligt lätt smutsat skum. Dofter av karamell och frukt. Smakinslag av karamell, blomster, malt och nöt. Mjuk och rund munkänsla.
Cask @ Fat Cat, Norwich. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and light hoppy - fruity. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet and moderate bitter finish. 180217

Cask @ Fat Cat, Norwich. Pours golden with an offwhite head. Aorma of malt, light caramel, light floral and grassy hops. Flavor is light sweet, malt, grassy and flowers. Medium body, soft carbonation. 180217
Cask @ The Fat Cat, Norwich. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are caramel, fruits, malt, hops and flowers. Nice hoppy finish.
Cask Pint at Doric Arch, Euston, London in Mar 2009 - Golden Amber in colour. Hoppy; floral & grassy hops (more subtle than expected). Malty base; caramel. Less bitter than expected. (2009-03)
Cask @ Gallows Bird, Espoo @ RAF XX. Pours orange. Aroma is caramel, flowers, quite nutty. Taste is full, mouth-filling, chewy. Nuts, caramel, flowery. Full. Very nice.

Cask @Gallows real ale festival. 
Pours golden color with a thin white head. 
Nutty dark fruity, peachy aroma. 
Flavor has peach, dark fruits, hops. Nice bitterness.

(Cask at Gallows Bird Real Ale Festival 2017) The beer poured amber and clear. Its head was small and white. Aroma had earth, toffee and malts. Palate was medium bodied with low carbonation. Flavours were earth, fruitiness, malts and bitterness. Aftertaste was hoppy and bitter. A pleasant hoppier bitter.

@Gallows Bird Real Ale Festival 2017pale malty, golden honey, dryish malty nose. Bit weak nose overall, bland. Med lightish bodied, honey malty, some citrus, dryish finish. Light buttery.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone

Draft at Ye Older White Horse. Dark brown and slick, small creamy beige head, lacing. The definition of mild, gentle in both aroma and taste, yet still full of flavor. Nice mouth feel, rolls off the tongue. Yakes the bottle experience and ratchets it up a notch.

Tap at the Jolly Drover, Liss, Hampshire/West Sussex, UK.
Medium, creamy head, golden/amber colour, clear. Aroma of berries with a small addition of malts. Bitter taste with a bit of sweetness. Medium body, soft carbonation. Nice one, especially with a burger and some chips after a busy day.

On cask at the Castle Tavern in Inverness. As a devotee of the bottled Landlord I was excited to see the cask version in my favourite pub in Inverness, and it was everything I expected. Soft pillowy malt character, firm bitterness and nice floral, spicy hop flavours and aromas. At proper cellar temperature a dream to drink, medium body and a smooth mouthfeel that is balance with the hop bite. Lovely beer.
A lovely beer. Pours a radiant colour with a small amount of foamy head. Tastes smooth and refreshing, some citrus and spices. Perhaps a bit too subtle but delicious nonetheless.
Pint on cask at the Beehive. Pours a cloudy light amber with a medium off-white head. Aromas of toffee, fresh bread, dry fruit. Bitter taste, some sweetness coming through.
Pours cloudy deep amber with low white head. Aroma of caramel, toffee, malt, light citrus. Taste is sweet with a mild bitter finish. Light and creamy body with soft carbonation.
Cask at The Cockpit, City of London, England. Clear amber. Bready malt aroma, intense fruitiness with red apples, floral hops. Medium bodied, low to medium carbonation. Dry, low to medium bitterness.
On tap at the Old Vine. Copper colour with a little head. Clean aroma and a beautiful slightly floral bitter taste with a little maltiness.  ---Rated via Beer Buddy for Android
Good solid balanced bitter - touch of sweetness, touch of bitterness and no off notes.
Cask at Dog & Gun Inn, Oxenhope. Clear amber colour with a nice white head. Citrus, dry fruits and malty aroma. Taste is bittersweet with biscuit and hoppy notes. Overall, nice beer.
Cask at Brownswood Tavern N5. Lightish amber with an off-white head. Aroma - malt, caramel, floral; Taste: biscuit, caramel, floral. Nice enough.
Fresh round malt aroma, with a bit more bitter hop bite than some of the others I have tried in this style. Quite nice.
Cask at the Cock & Lion, light brown with a thin head, malty nose with hints of citrus and toffee, dry-sweet and bitter, hints of earth and wood.

Cask at The Mitre, Manchester. A clear amber colour with a medium white head. Aroma of caramel, some toasted malts, slight biscuit and subtle earthy hops. Taste of toasted malts, some biscuit, slight caramel, a little yeast and subtle earthy hops. Light bodied and soft carbonation. A dryish, toasted malt bitterness in the finish. A basic, safe bitter. Nothing wrong with it, just better beers out there.

Cask @ The Three Fishes, Shrewsbury. Pours clear amber. Aroma is light, bready. Taste is perfectly fine, slightly bready, creamy. Inoffensive cask ale that doesnt quite hit the high notes by modern standards.
Cask in Blur Pig, Grantham. Golden, hazy with a thin white head. Slightly off aroma, taste is pleasant, fairly standard bitter, but nothing special. Might be past its best? One to try again...
One of the truly great draft bitters. Perfect balance of hops and malt. Creamy.
Pours clear light amber. Toasty, biscuit malts and hop spice. Nicely balanced , sweet dry fruits and hop spice.
Cask at Brasshouse; clear amber pour with a big creamy white head, aroma has light citrus some robust malts and red fruits, taste has rich malts, red berries, nice creamy mouthfeel, bitter finish.
UPDATED: MAR 13, 2017 Tastes of caramel and old mans pubs. But when fresh has some classic dried hops to it. Decent bitter but nothing special.

Cask at the George and Dragon in Chichester, at the recommendation of locals who praised the condition of Landlord on these premises. Clear golden amber color, white head. Aroma of caramel and light fruit. Taste is lightly bitter caramel, light body. Easy drinking but uninspiring.

@ The Rising Sun Berko. Pours a lightish amber with hints of haze and a small light tan head. The smell is toasted malt, biscuit, a bit earthy. The taste is toasted malt, biscuit ending with grassy dry hops. The body is light+ withmild/fine carbonation.
Pretty decent bitter. Light to moderate malt, a touch of sweet caramel, biscuit, slightly fruity mild bitter finish. Good session ale.
Clear amber beer with a thin head. Light, bready smell. Taste is tangy fruit and hops. I think itd be sickly over a session but its nice.

Cask. At Walton hotel - so overpriced. Resinous hoppy nose. Copper with thin top. The awards come from its balance and it remains a beer that others should study precisely because they go overboard on hops. Or arcane flavours.If this was the only beer available I would be happy if bored.
Cask at Bennets. Peppery spice and biscuit maltiness. Very smooth and drinkable. For me this pretty much sets the benchmark for traditional bitters.

Cask at The Garden House, Durham, £3.75/pint. 

Pours mid-amber with thin white head. Aroma is lightly biscuity, woody and nutty. Opens with slight fruity sweetness before a long, bitter finish on a very smooth palate. Good. Justifiably has a great reputation and a great all-rounder, but there are definitely more exciting beers out there.

On Cask with a sea view at the Old Chain Pier, Trinity, Edinburgh. Looks good in the foreground of a stunning scene. Creamy head. Golden amber. Biscuity aroma. It is indeed a nice Bitter with good old fashioned bitter to malt sweetness ratio. Quaffable, smooth, nutty caramel. Not my favourite style but appreciated. Aye...

Cervesa amb aroma lleuger, en boca predominen els tocs a caramel i galeta molt ben integrats.
Cerveza con aroma ligero, en boca predominan los toques a caramelo y galleta muy bien integrados.
Better than the bottle. Golden body with medium head. Nose is hoppy, floral and grassy. Taste caramel, maltier and nutty. Gets more bitter and hoppier in the finish. Enjoyable.

From cask at The Vine Inn, Manchester, with KL and LH 08.05.15. Golden. Uneven and diminishing off-white head and lacing. Slightly fruity aroma of malt and pale caramel. Similar taste. Very moderate bitterness in aftertaste. Good drinkability, though.

Aroma: caramel, milk, banana, yeast, citrus, lemongrass; Appearance: pale golden, minimal head; Taste: medium bitterness, slight sourness, slight sweetness; Palate: bitter finish, light body, watery texture, soft carbonation
Come across this on tap in loads of local pubs around Rochdale and it never dissapoints looks good in the glass and enough hops and flavour to make it interesting a great session beer

Lovely amber color with a thick white head. Solid lacing on the glass. Fruity and floral aroma. Flavor are mostly the same with a nice smooth toffee backbone. A mild and yet tasty pint.[Cask at The Albion in Goldsmiths Row London, England]

On tap. Straw color in the glass with a large froth of white foam. Light floral hops and sweet malt in the aroma. Taste is mostly sweet malt with some floral hops and bitterness. Smooth mouthfeel. Nice.
Pint on tap. Spicy hop nose. Honey coloured beer with pale thin head. Spicy rich taste followed by toffee notes and spicy hop finish. Delicious!
A lightbrown beer with white top. The taste is sweet with lot of hop and malt and hints of grass and lemon shreds.
Cask at the Shore. Pours golden yellow, light and fruity, slight butter finish.

On tap, half pint at The Argyll Arms, London. Clear deep golden color with thick creamy white head and soft visible carbonation. Aroma of grassy and floral hops, caramel and toffee. Taste starts with light sweet caramel malt and nutty note, following is refreshing fruity and grassy with moderate bitter finish. Medium body, oily texture and soft carbonation in palate. Oh lord, incredibly smooth and easy drinking bitter...
Decent, refreshing session type bitter, with enough hops to make it very easy drinking.
A really amazing ale. Full of hop and malt flavours that leave you wanting more. An amazing session beer that can be drunk from sunrise until sunrise.

Pulled a half pint at the White Horse. Honey golden clear ale with substantial white foamy head that persists. Clean lemon aroma hints on top of rich clean malt. Little persistence in the mouthfeel that allows a quick sip to follow. Bitterness persists with slight hop sweetness on the back of the tongue.

Cask 1/2 pint, Jolly Sailor, Poole, England, UK.
Złote piwo o cienkiej pianie i łagodnym, chmielowym aromacie. W smaku cytrusowe z wyrazistą, chmielową goryczką na finiszu.
Classic English beer , lovely grassy caramel,bread hay taste,fantastic beer could drink this all night, hard to find anything better.
Overall: Grass, apple peel, lemon shreds.Note: Cask at The White Swan. Reviewed 2014-10-03.
Smooth, well balanced and flavoursome beer. Amber coloured, with a good head and lacing. Medium bodied, soft carbonation. Sweet toffee malts and some citrus zest, perfectly offset by the bitterness.
Pint i London. Antagligen en av de bättre pinterna i London av dumma av recensionerna.
Cask @ The Black Bull in Blaydon. Served in clean Timothy Taylor Pint Glass, Perfect temperature, head size/retention, sweet flavour, subtle bitter finish. Truly awesome. I could drink it all night.

Cask, on this occasion in the Black Cat, Chesham. Bright golden amber colour. Solid malty base, lovely hop attack, marmelade, spicy, slightly earthy, not overpowering, moreish bitter. Hops pull through the house yeast flavour, which seems to need the hops, I dont like say the Golden Best anywhere near as much. One of those beers that no longer tastes as outlandishly flavourful given the increased bitterness and hop quotients used in more recent times, but still retains excellent balance.

Cask @ Foxtons restaurant, Berwick. Orange/amber colour, white foam. Creamy foam. Medium carbonation. Very well balanced bitter. Aroma of caramel, grapefruit and hops. Light sweet with light bitter finish. Good!

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2014 Sep 2014 - Cask at the Dove, Hackney.  Hazy dark amber / orange, still, decent off-white head leaves some thick lacing.  Aroma is sweet toffee, some light citrus.  Body is medium, light carbonation, smooth.  Taste is smooth toffee malt, semisweet malts are more prominent than hop character, very soft bitterness.  A classic, but too malt-heavy for my taste.  (3.2)
Nov 2014 - Cask at the Talbot, Dalston.  Hazy orange, still, small white head, some thick lacing.  Aroma is light malts.  Body is medium to light, smooth, low carbonation.  Taste is biscuity malt, tangy, soft bitterness.  On slightly better form than last time.  A dependable bitter. (3.3)
A very fine bitter. Somewhat sharper on the palate than many traditional Yorkshire bitters, and with a good lasting finish. Pleasing caramel colour. One to seek out.

Amber colour, nice balanced flavour. Starts of with sweet caramel flavour and has a slightly bitter finish. Very nice 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Cask, orange pour, white head, nose is caramel, taste is caramel, some fruit, awesome.
Cask @ The Star, Haywards Heath. Clear light orange color, small beige head. Smell and taste malts, caramalts, bitter, a hint of apple somehow. Average body and carbonation.
On tap at a pub in Eastbourne. Very smooth and mild one with nice balance. Some torf, nuts, hops and malt in the mix. Very easy drinkable and very quaffy. High quality beer.

Cask in Eastbourne @Matello Inn. Pours out in a deep amber-brown colour with smooth head and medium body. Aroma of malt and barley. Taste of mild hops, wheat, barley, nuts, caramel, light torf and malt. Smooth and nice to drink, enjoyed it.
Cask at the Albion, Epsom. Pours golden with a thin white head. Biscuit malt aroma. Bitter finish. Great session beer.
An excellent all round British bitter beer, a mainstay of Northern Ale. Sip or Session!

Cask, Eaten by Monsters, Carlisle. I was surprised that this hadnt been rated much earlier, but there ya go. Sometimes you forget just how good a standard English beer can be. In these days of US & NZ hop overloads (which are mighty fine), sometimes the right combination of English fuggles and goldings can produce a classic. Landlord is such a beer. Beautiful amber colour, bready and malty, with plenty of biscuit. A nice tangy finish, which is very moreish and when its in as good a condition as this pint was, I could happily drink it all night.

Cask at The Beehive. Pours clear amber with a medium, frothy off-white head, medium retention with excellent lacing. Aroma is toast malt, light fruity esters, earthy and woody hops. Flavor is malt forward with medium hops and bitterness and a dry finish. Medium to light body and medium carbonation.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2015 Clear, amber ale, with low carbonation and a diminishing white, foamy head. A little light-bodied, but by no means watery. Malts of caramel, bread and biscuit are well balanced by spicy and peppery hops, with notes of peaches and citrus. A lovely, refreshing beer, particularly for the summer; would love to have it again!

This was the first beer I tried at the British Beer Festival, and it was a great way to start. It had great spice and fruit notes and was perfectly balanced. Too bad I would probably have to fly to England to try it again.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2016 Pint at the Turks Head, Heinghton, Lincoln. Poured a clear amber colour with a thick off-white. Aroma has a slight sweet citrus, with faintly of hops. Tasted again of citrus, orange and with a mild bitter finish. Light body. A smooth eefreshing drink.

Appearance- very clear, amber, orangey, small foamy white head. Aroma- juicy fruit hints, malty yeast, toffee, hint of bread. Taste- smooth, malts, bit of lingering bitterness, medium to full mouthfeel, hint of lemony citrus, caramel and toffee, bit of toasted bread. Really nice bitter.
Lansdown Arms, Lewes - One of the best pints Ive ever tasted! Sweet, smooth, hoppy and delicious.
Cask at Blue Aid Maid. Amber color with white head. Aroma is mild; with aromatic malt notes and mild hop notes. Taste is mild, vinous, malty.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2015 Rerate because its good and I didnt rate it that good. Amber with a fluffy white head. aroma of caramel, dust, grass, light fruits and roasted malt hints. Taste of caramel, fruits, light sourness, followed by some light roasted malts and grass. Medium bitterness in the finish. Medium body.

Hardly any aroma but a strong pungent hoppy taste. Light golden brown colour. Quite a farmyard like lingering aftertaste. Not a massive fan. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Cask at Pillars of Hercules, London, UK. Pours bronze amber, flower aroma, fruity hoppy flavor. Great bitter.

Aroma: floral hops. Appearance: golden clear light, small head. Taste: lightly sweet. Palate: medium to flat carbonation, malts continue the mild sweetness. Overall: fantastic bitter, fabulous taste - probably my favourite in this style. Pint at The Windsor Castle Kensington, London.
Cask 42 ossett. Dark amber colour decent white head good lacing. Aroma is sweet malts slight citrus well balanced with hop finish. Great body with smooth silky feel. Very good reliable pint.
Superb beer, as a homebrewer styrian goldings are one of my favourite hops and you can really taste them in this beer.
Medium head, nice floral hops aroma. Taste is pleasantly influenced by hops, and finishes on a bitter note. A very good beer.

Prince of Wales, Pimlico, UK.
Cask, 161013.
Golden with white head. Aroma of hay. Flavor with malt, citrus and fruit.
Always reliable, good taste and condition. Caramel notes. Session beer thats just as good in bottles or from the barrel.

Cask @ Cross Keys, Harpenden. Dark gold, almost copper. Very faint aroma. Working hard you can get toast, golden syrup, yeast. Bittersweet taste; syrup comes into play in a big way. Not as balanced as I remember.
Well-crafted enough but not the most exciting of best bitters.

Cask at Teuchters landing. Golden with white head. Spicy earthy aroma. Taste of intense toffee, peppery earthy hops, something weird I cant put my finger on, like Tizer. Slightly sweet. Not offensive but not for me.

pints in various places. pours a light amber with a very creamy head. aroma is great. lots of hops, a bit of yeast and some caramel and fruits. taste is super smooth. very refreshing. minimal carbonation.

Long standing favourite best hand pulled no so keen on bottled.
Surprised this beer has not won more recent awards.
One of my longtime favourites and readily available here in West Yorkshire.
Amber with a good white head. Good bittersweet taste with a nice balance between malt and hop flavours. Bitter, fruity and hoppy. A classic.
Had this several times including Berts in Edinburgh. Always a good session ale with a nice level of hops and malt. golden color and a nice head

Cask at the Fighting Cock, Bradford, September 2013. Bright gold with white head. Pumpkin seeds and jasmine aroma, very little butterish taste, a little burning and mildly bitter. Medium body, long, nettle-like finish.
Half pint somewhere in London. Golden, slightly cloudy amber. Nice bitter sweet balance. Not an amazing beer, but easy to drink.

Cask at Thomsons. Pours golden yellow with good white head. Merest touch of carbonation. Aromas of bready malt and spicey hops. Some honey on the taste, but good balancing bitterness. Much better than the bottle.

Sweet malty light caramel base, with some slight hopping on the palate. Drunk this many times in different places and never has a bad pint of this. Classic bitter.

Classic ale....tasty, good lasting taste, full
Bodied. Worthy of its status
One of the best bitters I've had. Lots of flavor and aroma of sweet malt. Orange/yellow little head but nice lacing. Had at the Blue Posts in London.

Cask at the Mug House, Bewdley. Pours dark orange with a small head. Aroma is creamy, bready malt with a touch of banana from the hops. Taste has lots of bready malt and toast with a strong bitter finish. Touch if sulphur. Creamy mouthfeel.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2016 My Bottom Line:
This super smooth, quintessential Bitter marries leafy, orangey hops to honeyed, lightly caramelized malts for an impeccable pint.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A sticky head of foam covers the clear amber, lacing beautifully.
-Drinkability is very high.
-The nose could be better developed, in my tastes anyway.
-The leafy hop bitterness is long lasting.
-A subtle peppery spiciness gives the flavour profile more depth.
-A mineral touch is found in the nose (not nearly as intense as the one I had gotten in the bottled version).

On cask at The White Horse, Oxford, at The Dripping Springs, St. Leonards and at The Albion, Hastings.

The best bitter I have ever tasted, beautiful hoppy finish and lingering maltiness. But the head disappears a bit too quickly in this Cambridgeshire pub; it just doesnt travel too well outside Yorkshire!
Lovely hop taste and lasting aftertaste that leaves you wanting more. I wanted a second pint after just one mouthful.

On cask. Pours a cloudy amber. Beautiful balanced palate with medium bitterness

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

[cask, the Woolpack Inn, York] Clear golden pour in Yorks newest pub that has all TT beers on at once  a great resource for a ticker. However, after a half of this and the Golden Mild, I left. Overly sweet, creamy, biscuity hay-like aftertaste, very little flavour. Disappointed [17052013]

Tasted 22/4/2013 draught "The Harrison", Kings Cross, London. Poured a clear amber colour with a 5mm thick off-white bubbly head that laced OK. Aroma sweet citrus and faintly of hops. Tasted slightly sweet (citrus, orange) fading to a mild bitterness. Light body. A smooth, soft, light ale with a sweet and very faint bitter finish. Refreshing; easy drinking.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2014 Cask at Berts Bar. Clear amber body with a small white head. Light lacing. Aroma of wax, white pepper and peach. Very light, subtle aroma. Flavour is very soft and delicate. Orange marmalade and biscuit with a light peppery spice. Medium body with a flat, oily texture. Very smooth and drinkable.
Weak on the nose. Creamy texture with a light fizz. Horrible soggy-cornflakey flavour going on. Would not buy again.
One of the most reliable pints you can get in a good London pub. Very smooth and delicate taste with traces of orange, citrus. Refreshing for an ale.
Good beer depends on how it is kept and served, not just the brew itself.  This, however, is one of the most consistently excellent beers with truly great taste.
Great beer and would usually choose this as my first beer when available as you know what your getting.  2nd and 3rd may choose something else as I get more adventurous

Normally a plain style. However, this is the best pint Ive ever found in Scotland. Kept ordering up more. Pour was golden to orange, a typical handpulled smooth head thay sustains itself quite well. Lacing smooth. Aroma of earthiness and some citrus and fruits. Flavor is citrusy, woody, earthy, fruity, with a nice grainy malt base balanced in there. Nothing sticky, caramel-like, toffee, etc.... Just a nice clean smooth brew. Hats off to TT. Enjoyed in Braughty Ferry area.
On cask at Newton Arms Ayr citrus and tropical flavours mixed nice hop malt ballance with Sweet smooth flavour

Apparently not  the easiest of beers to keep,but this pub knows how to look after it,s ales. golden brown with tight head,nice combination of malt and fruits with a good balance all round. A very good session beer that ticks all the right boxes. I am struggling to find any reason to criticise it.

This can be so variable. On form, it is great. Kept badly this is a poor pint. Fortunately mein host (at the Old Red Lion Theatre, Angel) kept it well. It pours a nice orang/gold colour, with a decent Northern head of off white foam....and you still get this, even though we are now in the South. The aroma is of crisp British hops - nothing tropical here, but still fruity. On the palate, this is crisp and fresh, but with a good counterbalance of sweetness to balance out the (what is for a traditional British hop) quite complex hop profile. As I say, when its good, its very good.
Great bitter.  I always get excited when I see this offered on cask.  Its soft mouthfeel and easy drinking nature make it the perfect session beer.

Cask at the Prince of Wales, Aberdeen. It pours golden amber with a medium white head. The nose is fairly restrained...dough, hay, wood, earth and touch of sweetness. The taste is dry straw, grass, pithy citrus, wood, spice, earth, decent bitterness and some soap with a dry finish. Medium body and soft carbonation. Pretty so-so... an ok bitter but there are many better out there.
light chesnut brown with a persistent creamy head. Nutty sweet malty aroma. Crisp zesty hop finish. Well balanced and very drinkable./

4.3% deep gold colour with a good head, malt aroma, fruit, hoppy flavour fairly dry and bitter, also good in bottles.  It was lovely outside the Grosvenor Hotel at the top of Robin Hoods Bay, on a warm September afternoon.

On cask at the Atholl hotel, pours a dark amber with no head and some medium lacing around the edges, aroma is sweet, malty easy Smelling  taste of sweet malt, decent 'real ale' yeasty notes, nothing special but very easy drinking 

via Beer Buddy

cask at Bulls Head, Meriden
Pours clear golden amber with sweet malt and slight lemon nose. Dry, clean bitterness, biscuit malt.

Pours darkish amber, smooth and almost creamy.
Fist taste of the day has a sweet fruity snap with citrus notes that dies off and tranforms into a hoppy full bodied flavour.
Landlord is a lovely Ale one of my top 5. Its only down fall is it almost too drinkable. Easily a 7-8 Pinter. 

Note to self: must exercise restraint when drinking Landlord.

The only pub round my way to have it on pump is the White Horse in Sandway Maidstone Kent. Luckly a 10 min walk for me. 

Rates 3 out of my top 5!!!

On cask at Babelas, Leicester. 
I havent had a pint of Landlord for ages, I used to think it was nice but had recently been into more "fashionable" hoppier beers and had got fed up with people either raving about it or "its boring" or even worse "its not what it was"   
But you know what it was delicious tonight, a grapefruit smell/taste that I never detected before ( I have given up smoking since last time I had it- about 18 months ago by the way). Really nice. AND its from Yorkshire like me.

On cask at the Royal Oak, Wirkswirth.
AMber color, good foam.
Good fruitiness
Medium body & complexity.
Well balanced and enjoyable

Easily my favorite English cask ale. Pours super creamy, with a soft hop aroma and malty nose. Taste is velvet on the tongue, with a little sweetness, giving way to a flinty dryness. Lacing all the way to the bottom of the glass.
Love it.
Mmmmmmmm pure gold. A perfect English pint for any occasion. Cant wait till my next one.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2013 Cask at the Harvester, Solihull.  Clear golden brown pour, thin frothy head and broken lacing. A classic English bitter that isnt quite so bitter!  Big malty flavour with a smooth bitter taste which only just reaches the palate. It has an almost creamy feel to it, which probably explains its popularity.  Its been the king of English bitters for a while now and shows no sign of losing its crown.

Cask @ The Cleveland Arms. Ahhh, Landlord, how have I gone so long without rating you? Perhaps because youre such forgettable beer. Medium amber color with a creamy white head. This does look attractive. The nose is straw, bread, light herb. Faint aromas. The taste is moderately malty notes of toffee, some yeasty brown bread and not much more. Medium body, soft. Theres a difference between being well balanced and boring. This is a boring, stodgy chore of a pint. Overall, I really dont know how this beer still has a big reputation. Perhaps it used to be better? I can think of so many bitters Id rather drink.

Not as brilliant as I remembered it but maybe because there are now soooooo many good bitters on the market?   This is a good session bitter. This is not a very complex beer.  Medium body pours a nice smooth head. Smooth to drink, ringing hops floral fruit hints, clean finish.

Cask at the Half Moon, Windlesham - 22/08/12.
Clear golden copper with a minimal white head that soon thins.
Caramel malt nose with a little hops.
Malt forward taste, caramel, toffee, biscuit.
Medium bodied with moderate carbonation and a bitter finish.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Fra håndpumpe på The Grenadier, London SW1. Pubcrawl med Julian, jan-11: en benchmark blandt engelske bitter. Kompleks, smaksrik og med god munnfylde. Lett å like, lett å drikke.
Golden bitter. Very clean, easy to drink session beer. Well balanced with slightly bitter finish.

Cask at Black Lion, Westminister:
Strong, fruity aroma that is mainly orange and cirtus notes along with some tarty aromas and a little bit of acidity. There is some grassy notes and a touch of biscuit mixed with the malts.

Orange amber colour with a thick and bubbly white head that stays consistent for the duration.

Fruity to begin along with some mild acidity and tart. The summer fruits flavours are quite nice and I can also detect a bit of caramel.

Smooth with a tiny bit of acidity and a medium to full and creamy body. Carbonation is low and there is some fruity tart at the end with a wet finish.

This one was a particularly nice cask beer and a great start to the morning seeing that is was very easy to drink and had a good , lingering fruity aftertaste along with a nice feel to it that was one of the more refreshing cask beers.
Copper colour with a frothy white head. Hop, fruit aroma. Smooth yet has a slight tangy finish.
Golden. Creamy white head. Good lacing. Lemon, light fruits, and caramel. Superb balance.

Cask by handpump at Ship Inn, Dumfries - clear golden amber ale, thin off-white head, mild floral / fruity aroma, caramel malt and fruity hop flavour, medium body and carbonation, neither bitter nor sweet, quite bland

Cask. Golden, rusty colour. White head. Aroma is fruity and taste is fruity, malty, sweet and ends bitter. its very smooth. I cant say I was especially impressed, but it generally gets a good rating.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2012 A very nice  IPA sharp  fruity hops  mellowed by the malt. notes of orange zest and pine cones.
very smooth mouthfeel.  
not as  aggressive as other IPAs but it is  more balanced 
 A great session beer.

Cask @ The Winstor Castle, London. Deep golden body with a small off-white head. Quite mild and fruity aroma. Smooth and mils flavor of malt and mature fruit with a pleasant bitterness. Medium body and decent aftertaste. Nothing special going on here, but a decent beer within the classic bitter style.

Orange/amber, clear, thin head; bitterness from the off, nice deep fruitiness, a little orange, a little plum; good depth of flavour; bitter finish; undeniably good, but four-time Champion Beer of Britain?!

Pint at the Wheatsheaf in Corbridge. This stuff has been around since the Dark Ages, and is possibly the ultimate "default pint". I can honestly say that on the occasions I have drunk this beer it has never disappointed. A good solid English bitter that you have no excuse for not trying.

December 2006: 3 Pints taken in The Plough Inn Allscot, Shropshire. A well known (to locals) Real Ale pub near Telford. A straight pint sleeve glass, unbadged. 

Light brown with a hint of copper, topped with a fairly large white foaming head, which lasted for most of the pints (about 15 mins each). 

Aroma of hops, malt and a flowery, fruity undertone. 

Tastes dryish, hops and malt, with summer fruits swilling about as well. 

Dry aftertaste, didnt last long, even after the third pint. 

A very pleasant drink, a bit light in colour for me, I like a bronze, darker hue to my beers, but I have drank this beer in many different locations and enjoyed it every time we meet.

For a traditional bitter this has to be one of the best. Caramel rather than biscuit. Enough hops to balance and refresh. And full palate which is clean and never cloying. Nice.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Half at the Queens Arms, Birmingham.  Clear gold amber with off white head.  Fruity malt hoppy aroma and flavour.

Sample at queens arms bar, Birmingham.
Decent creamy white head.  Clear golden blond pour.  Very nice.
An average bitter, but then again, I tend to find bitters average. Extremely drinkable.

Pint, apple juice like colour, clear with medium head. Nice Golding hop aroma with notes of apples. Tasted fruity,was well balanced with a fairly long bitter finish. Mouthfull was smooth and didnt have too much carbonation. Overall very good bitter with character and sessionability.

Cask at the Grenadir London. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Heavy bitter wonderfull flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. Creamy palate. Great balance.
Pint in London. Cloudy orange with a medium lasting head. Aroma is spice citrus. Flavour is tangy hop with a long bitter dry hop palate

Tasted this in the Blythswood Bar, Glasgow in June 1992. Cask, handpump dispense. Opaque pale orange amber in colour with a thin creamy white head. Strong citrus fruit flavours of orange and lemon peel present in the long nose. Thin but refreshing mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malts give a digestive biscuit base with toffee and tangerine fruit layered in this. Earthy notes to the hoppy prickle of a subdued bitter aftertaste. Finish is slightly malty with hints of tart redcurrant evident in the mouth. A decent session bitter and well recommended.

Hand pulled. Golden amber with a cream lasting head. Very vinegary nose - on the verge of being unpleasant. Bitter mouth taste. Creamy, malty and moreish. Decently long creamy finish. Not as long as bottle conditioned, but nice.

Pint in Fellows Morton and Clayton, Canal Street, Nottingham.  Having looked at the ratings Im wondering if I drank the same bitter.  It looked ok - a clear, pale brown/amber - but lost marks for the small, soapy head and the speed at which that dispersed.  The taste and aroma werent bad - a slightly dry, medium bitter with light hops -  but it was too abrupt and was soon giving way to a watery, hoppy aftertaste which didnt have any power.  It didnt have anything to make it stand out from the crowd.
Very smooth in the palate and easy to drink with a subtle flavour among the bitterness.
Drucken på fat på London pub jag inte minns namnet på. Frisk citrushumlekaraktär, lätt kropp, väldigt lättdrucken i positiv bemärkelse.

Light gold with soapy white head. Light.vineger. Fruity, maybe mango?, caramel. Some unapealing hint in the oder. Sweet light caramel feel. Medium dry bitter taste.and a light fruity finish. Very right and.full of flavour.

Tap @ The Museum Tavern. Pours pale amber with a small off white heasd leaving lacing. Aroma is nicely fruity, malty, herbal and hoppy. Flavor is fruity, sweet, bitter and floral with a small touch of maltiness. Finishes dry and bitter.

A - Fruity citrus and some tea
A - Medium gold, with thick white head
T - Light sweet with long light bitter
P - Medium and soft
O - Good citrusy bitter
Poured clear amber with a thin creamy off-white head. Fruity aroma. Light mouthfeel. Sweet flavour, caramel malt and peach notes. Bitter finish.

UPDATED: AUG 23, 2011 Re-rate from cask @ Berts Bar. This time the taste and the palate were much better, with more citrus in the taste and more of a clean finish.   

Previous rating 6/3/5/2/9 = 2.5
Cask @ Teuchtars. Pours golden-amber  with a nice sized head. The nose is quite elusive but it has pine and strangely some cream soap. The taste has appley-oxidation, creamy pine, then a burnt note. The palate is medium boded and textured, but rather than a clean note, theres a malty overhang on the end. Overall, this is disappointing and I suspect it is not at its best in this encounter. The bottle was more enjoyable.

Pint at the Goose in Bracknell.  Lively orange colour with a slight bubbly head.  Bitter with citrus fruit.  I got over the bitterness and a couple of gob fulls though and always enjoy this.  Nice fruity hop aroma.

Cask at the Windsor Castle. 
Deep gold with a nice fine head. Big (noble?) hoppy nose, light malt. Similar to a good Czech pils to me. Big hoppy flavor, grassy, with mint, light golden malt, some bread. Not sweetjust a bit warming. Prickly though light carbonation. Peppery, bitter finish. Very nice.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2012 2nd rate Highlander Inn, Craigellachie 231112
The first rating of this was an early rate for me
Appearance as before, not much lacing or head retention
Aroma - soft spicy hops, golden caramel malts, not much else
Taste of spicy bitter hops, golden caramel malts, grainy malts, some toasted barley, its getting boring for me now
Palate - thin to medium body, soft carb, tangy spicy palate. Finish as main flavour.
Overall - Not as good as it used to be - either my palates changed or its gone downhill...less flavour more water...big downrate 3.9 > 3.1



Cask @ Rose and Crown, Findhorn...... Appearance - Golden brown, clear, 1 finger white head......Aroma - grassy hop, yeast, caramel malt, floral and spicy notes, bit of cereal...Taste - bitter grassy hop, yeasty, caramel and bread malts, floral notes, bit peppery quite complex....Palate - Nice sharp bitterness in mouth with a good bitter tangy finish. Overall...a unique bitter in flavour, one of the very best bitters in the UK, and is widely available. I never get bored with this. 7/4/8/4/16 080711
On cask at The Ship Inn, Broughty Ferry.  One of the better widely available real ales.  A good balance of malt and hops with a hint of dark fruits.  A good session ale.
Pint @Castle Tavern Inverness. Fairly enjoyable, quite hearty.  Slight breadiness - overall, good for the gentle creeping thirst.

Cask at Trengilly Wartha Inn. Pours clear nut brown with a tiny white head. Aroma of flowers and caramel. Taste is good nutty malts with some fresh bitter hops, which lingers to the bitter end. Good beer, but...
On cask. Pours a clear golden colour with a dense white head. Caramel, yeasty nose. Caramel, malt and some fruity hop flavours also. Pleasantly bitter with lingering dryness. Quite respectable.

Pint from cask at White Horse in Oxford. Smells hoppy and a bit grassy. Tastes very fresh with a predominant bitter note (but not a strong bitter) with hints of hops and malt and a very small hint of grass -- a pleasant taste of the mixture of flavors. Very smooth and creamy with good lacing. Finish is light bitter and dry. Drinkable and pleasantly enjoyable -- but its just that: a pleasant session beer.

Pours copper with medium white head that dissipates quickly. Nose is dominated by fruity hops, freshly baked bread and bit of citrous. Taste is big fruity English hops. Complex hop notes and very bold in the mouth. Served flat - no carbonation. Wouldnt really call this a session beer. Bit too bold and fruity.
Cask @ The Lyric, Soho. Pours copper, with a fluffy off white head. Fruity, slight toffee, and a touch of honey. Bit thin and watery.

I dont like English ale at all... but I like this one.  Like all English ales, it stinks when its poured and its flat.  It tastes darn good though!  A lot of ales try to be this good.  The local pub had it all the time and it was fresh and good and I never had a bad glass.  I cant say that for most english ales I had.  Its a nice hearty pint of GOOD ALE!

Draught in The Bell, Hove - 8/1/11. Beautiful looking pint. Lovely, hoppy taste. Slight sweetness on the early palate giving way to a dry, hoppy finish. Pleasently coats the mouth when drinking. A very special beer.

Handpump at a random pub near the palace in London. Nice orange color with good clarity and a firm but small white head. Floral and fruity aroma with a nice hoppy touch and bready malt as well. Hoppy flavor, but with a great bready and nutty malt balance. Medium body and overall pretty dry. A very nice best bitter, and very well-kept.
Good beer. Light to medium body and flavor. Gold to amber color. minimum citrus. Subtle hops, easy on the aftertaste, fragrant and clean.

From Good Beer Guide recommended pub Old Queens Head, Aldham, Essex. I have found Timothy Taylor Landlord to be a bit hit and miss and rather over rated in the past, but this one yesterday was served up really well and was an enjoyable pint.

Cask.
Clear golden coloured with a small white head.
Fruity aroma of malts, caramel, grass and hops.
Fruity flavour of grass and hops.
Dry hoppy finish.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2012 Cask @ Cloisters, Edinburgh & The Bon Accord. Golden brown colour, not much head. Dry caramel malt aroma. Caramel citrus malt flavour. flavour & aroma. Bitter aftertaste. Big tasting bitter but vastly over-rated.

Cask at Bow Bar, Edinburgh, Scotland. Clear dark golden colour, creamy white head. Aroma is very fruity and malty, melon, pineapple, a bit of honey. Flavour is much the same with a good dry bitter finish. Light bodied.

Really?
Maybe its just me, but one of the words I wrote in taking notes was rubbish - partially because its a cheeky little british word and partly because I thought the beer was somewhat rubish.
I thought this was going to be a light beer, pale ale of bitters that wasnt rated very highly.  It did have some nice grassy flavors but that was about it really.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2013 Tap at Argyll Arms. Pours a clear, copper-gold with a faint, bubbly white head. Ginger cake aroma, malty, with very little hops. Lightly sweet flavor, quite malty with more cake notes, mild spices, and perhaps the faintest hints of bitterness. Medium in body with fine carbonation. Has a sweet finish with easy, earthy bitters finally acting up. (3.6)Cask at the Cleveland Arms, London. Pours clear, rich gold with a lasting, off-white foam head. Aroma holds some juicy berries, doughy brown bread. Lifht sqeet flavor with toasty sugars, tasty bread, light leafy bitterness, light esters. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Superb condition. Great finish, moderate bready malt sweetness, light leafy hops, further berries. Just an absolute classic bitter. On form this is hard to beat. (4.0)

On tap at Horniman at Hays. This one had more flavour then the other beers I tried, some flowers, hops and bread in the smell. White it had a taste of flowery hops, bread, rosehip and fruits. Fairly mild but stronger then the previous ales I tried.
Draught at the Cherry Tree, Peterborough Poured golden with crisp white head. Hoppy bitterness in aroma. Somewhat light bodied, pleasant mouth feel. Pleasant hoppy flavour well balanced with malts.

Cask at the Great British Beer Festival 2010, served in an English pint glass. Pours hazy amber with a tall, frothy white head. Head has good retention and leaves good lace. On the nose, it is primarily piney hops with significant floral and pale malt notes. The flavour is balanced between moderately sweet malts and light hops. The finish is long and roasty malts. On the palate, it is light in body with a smooth texture and very light carbonation. Overall, this is a great bitter. Remarkable among English bitters for its hoppy profile. It also has a nice roasty finish. 2010-08-04
ambrata poca schiuma naso piuttosto luppolato leggero caramelo un po  citrico finale luppolato

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2014 The beer on which many micro-ales were modelled. Only one feature really, and that is the strong almost overpowering hop aroma. However, if you take too long to drink it, the last few gulps can be very acid on the palate. For all that, a great beer.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2014 Cask. The Brunswick, Derby (1/6/2010). Grassy hop; caramel malt, well balanced. Thin white head that doesnt last. Clear gold amber.  Low to medium bitterness. Some oiliness on the palate but on the whole crisp and fresh. 8 4 8 4 16 ### Cask at the Oak, Hutton Magna (20/4/2014). Amber body. Medium white head. Nose is peppery, oranges, hops, spice, red fruit, yeast, caramel, honey, green apple and herbs. Bitter with some tang. Dry finish. Crisp mouthfeel. 7 4 7 4 14
cask at some shithole in Bath. Served from a sparkler. super clean, crisp, zome nice veggie, biscuit, parsley notes. mild ekg. very easy drinking. excellent!

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2010 (Old BA rate - cask) 
Lighter gold in color, with a wonderful pure white head. The lacing would not stop throughout the sample. Hops are the dominant aroma, and tended to overshadow the malts (but the malt was still there). Great hop bitterness, and the hops were a bit more flowery in aroma. Some fruitier malt tastes. Slicker mouthfeel, with a light medium body. Next to no carbonation. Hugely drinkable, and sessionable. Overall, this was a great brew, and I was excited to have the chance to taste it on cask while in the UK. It was bone dry in the finish
Cask. Amber colored brew. Aroma is malty. Flavor is malty too, bitterness, overall a bit dull.
Light petrol and oily malts on the nose.  very satisfying to drink. Long smooth malts and drying skunky hops. Amazingly drinkable. knock that back all night.
Cask. Pours an almost clear pale amber with a creamy off-white head. Nutty nose. Medium body, some sticky caramel and nuts. Lightly hoppy finish. 190110

Pours honey gold with minimum beige head. Peppery hops, definite floral hops, and malt in the aroma. Taste is citrus, pepper, and brown sugar. There is just a bit of a bitter linger. Very well done bitter.
Pint on draft at the Bear & Staff, London. Fruity smell, a nice, malty, fruity taste that lasts. Hoppy finish but drinkable.
One of the best english beers you can try in my humble opinion. On cask at my wedding reception i regarded it so highly. Balanced sweet lovely quaffable beer.

Sample taste I had was somehow better than the 1/2 pint. Poured with a small off white head that quickly disappeard and no lace. Very clear amber color. Aroma was malty, hoppy, and a touch fruity. Body was decent, ditto carbonation. Nice finish. Session beer.

Cask @ Woking Beer Festival 2009.  Excellent light amber session bitter. Good hop aroma with plenty of caramel in the taste. Finishes with a clean bitterness. Overall one of the best session bitters around.
Cask at The Cambridge, Charing Cross Rd, London. Pours light amber. Pleasant, grassy aroma. Muted hops with a surprising apple aftertaste.

One finger cream head on a hazy, copper colored body. Smells yeasty with some light doughy malts and a scent of tinned fruits. Taste is light to medium sweet, smooth malty. Cask @ The Encore, Stratford-Upon-Avon, England. Carmel, color, Sweet caramel malt, medium bitterness, well balanced, smooth, quite good

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2011 20.09.2009, on tap at the Bow Bar, Edinburgh. Yellow colour with white head. Aroma is sweet malty with some grass or hay. Low bitterness. Aftertaste is spicey. (First rating 28.09.2007 at the Cambridge, London)

Nose: v malty, toast, honey, butter, nutty.
Taste: bitter orange, malt, light treacle, butter. 
Lovely and refreshing and I drank this in the perfect time and location - a warm afternoon in a pub garden.
Golden with a small white head. Aroma of citrus, pear and exotic fruit with a hint of butter. Sweet and fruity with goiod hop flavour and bitterness
Cask @ The Hospital Arms Colchester. Aroma of flowers and hops. Malty and hoppy flavour. Nice hoppy finish. Very nice!

Cask @ The Blue Flame in Nailsea. A hazy orange bitter with a small off-white head. Malty nose of caramel and floral hops that is not overpowering. Flavours of biscuity malts, subtle tangerine and delicious floral hops at the end. Creamy mouthfeel though quite light bodied. Extremely moreish and refreshing. Highly recommended.

Permanent cask at the Star, Highgate, London on 18/07/09. Amber colour with limited off-white head that dies halfway down the pint glass. Sweaty yeast on the nose. Moderate hoppiness is partly rivalled by caramelly malt. Quite a dry finish on a pleasant mouthfeel. Natural soft carbonation. The beer felt as though it was served a degree or two below design temperature.
Best drunk locally in Yorkshire where the flavour of the fresh ale is excellent

Got this one at a pub at the South end of the Blackfriars Bridge on the Thames in London.  A cloudy pumpkin orange with a nice, clean aroma.  Creamy on the mouth, like Im coming to expect of cask ales.  Very typical, good beer, with a nice bitterness on the finish.

Cask ale @ the Black Friar. Deep orangey gold a long cascade focuses into a cirrus head and phenomenal lace veil. Gentle aromas of lemon, musty hay, and sulfur. Subdued estery/buttery flavor with a grassy Golding twag. Light but smooth I might even say a rich mouthfeel. Very restrained and "plain" all around. Did not live up to hype and expectations; I have to admit I struggled to enjoy it.
Cask @ Bow Bar. Amber colour, white head. Aroma is hoppy and fruity. Flavour is hoppy, malty and fruity. Slightly bitter finish. Worth a rerate.
Cask at The Harp, London. This ale is always on top form at The Harp. Lingering bitterness and of course plenty of hops. Dangerously drinkable ale.

Cask at the Gunmakers in Clerkenwell. Citrus nose like soft grapefruit carries through, adding zest to a moderately bitter backdrop. Incredibly quaffable and really hits the spot. Was unable to resist the urge to have several more in a row.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2009  Not in the best condition but it was St Patricks day . Was a bit underwhelmed by this of cask.Not as hoppy or aromatic as ive heard.Ive liked the bottled version since first sample six years ago.Still pretty good despite these flaws.

(pint from handpump at the Cock Inn in Diss, Norfolk) Appearance was of medium golden with a good murky white head. Smell wasnt too powerful but a hint of malt and nice hops. Feels well balanced in the mouth, not overly smooth but full with a good lingering aftertaste. Tastes of floral hops with a delicate sweetness, and a bitterness that isnt overbearing. A somehow refreshingl, delicate, but full pint. In many pubs and actually one of the better bitters for its ABV out there. Usually first port of call if there is nothing else special. Very nice.

Nice golden/amber coloured body with a tannish head. Aroma of fresh hops, a bit of malt and a light amount of sweet caramel. Light-bodied; Very mild flavour with some malt and hops coming through, as well as some alcohol. Aftertaste shows light hops, flowers and a tiny bit of alcohol. Overall, a pretty good bitter - light, but showing good character. I sampled this beer on draught purchased at the York in Islington, London, England on 30-November-2008.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2015 Handpulled cask all over the place but never better than in a tied house local to the brewery. The Boltmakers Arms in Keighley is particularly good.  Orangy brown with an off white head.  Very distinctive flavour which has remained pretty constant over the years. Good citrus hop notes from the styrian goldings. This characturistic was virtually unique to this brewer for decades. Excellent balance with juicy malt base combine to leaving you wanting more.  A number of newer brewers have bettered this beer, but will they stand the test of time?

From cask at Cloisters. Pours slight cloudy orange with a small white head. Aroma is light caramel malty. First flavour impression on the tip of the tongue is sweet. Followed by a more fruity impression and ending medium dry and bitter. Dry yet also slight fruity finish.
This is an all round nice drink.  Nose of biscuit with a lemony elderflower hop presence.  Brilliant

Cask Conditioned at Woodin’s Shades, LondonGolden color. Like the Emerards Equinox tasted side to side, it has a light apple aroma. But this one at least has a normal body strength and some caramel flavor. Correct bitterness. Quite refreshing.
Heaven in a glass when looked after. Very widespread in UK, which has led to variable pints. This is fairly hoppy. Dark amber colour with a nice head lacing the glass. Floral.

Cask, Clear amber coloured beer with an average creamy white to off white head and no carbonation. Special fruity aroma with some hoppy touches. Creamy full palate. Finish is bitter fruity and hoppy. nice one.

Draught.  I wish it was 1985 when Everton was a decent team and Landlord was probably the best pint I’ve ever tasted.  Sadly, its popularity meant they had to expand and the beer suffered as a consequence.  Still a decent drop when on form.  Dark amber with large white head (when served properly, i.e. in the North).  Very floral hop aroma, Styrian Goldings I’ve been told.  Floral and fruity on the tongue with a pleasant dry finish.  Full-bodied for its ABV.  Still superb when well-kept.  Absolutely horrible otherwise.
Nice off blonde pint, little carbonation, quite viscous drink with good bitter taste, hoppy finish.  Nice.
UPDATED: SEP 6, 2008 While I think this is a very nice pint, it tastes good and has plenty of flavour, it isnt stand out as being amazing amazing amazing but its good.
Cask. Weak grainy aroma. Good creamy flavour and mouthfeel. Almost clear copper colour. The flavour has a distinct bitterness, not rough. Mild fruitiness. Good standard bitter.

Another cask that I was able to have while I was in London.  Pours a clear gold/amber with a white head.  Malty aroma.  A little sweet, nice malt flavor with just a little bit of bitterness.  Not too shabby.
Cask (GBBF 2008) - Golden in colour. Malty aroma with a light malt and hop balance. Clean tasting,malty and hoppy. Not bad and well made.
Cask. Golden amber coloured ale. Rich malty, creamy flavour with lovely hop background. Quite sweet with a little caramel thrown in there as well. One of the best bitters around.
Clear amber with tiny off white short lasting head. Sweet and fruity aroma with floral hops. Sweet and somewhat hoppy flavor with caramel notes and a bitter finish.

Draught. Hazy yellow amber with little head. Aroma of malt, flowery hops and fruit. Light to medium body, very little carbonation. The flavour is a beautiful balance of malt, hoppy bitterness and fruit (passion fruit?). Does beer get better than this?

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2016 [1st rating, cask at the Spade Oak, Bourne End. RB score 6/3/5/2/10 (2.6] Fairly pale for a traditional bitter, with a moderate lasting white head. Intensely, almost unpleasantly bitter on the first taste; this does mellow with time to reveal dusty straw and citrus hops.  Very clean and crisp-tasting for a bitter, but a little too bitter for my palatte Im afraid.  I can see why people like this, but for me theres some much nicer examples of the genre around - Goffs White Knight, Adnams East Green Carbon Neutral and Hidden Pint spring to mind. [2nd rating, cask at the Saracens Head, Beaconsfield. RB score 5/3/6/3/11 (2.8)]. Score entered is an average of all rates.
UPDATED: JUL 30, 2008 fairly strong floral/hoppy aroma, flavours of dry lemon, grass, orange peel. smooth mouthfeel with a dry-bitter finish.

Cask RA. Golden coloured beer. Hints of lemon and grapefruit aromas in
the taste. Suitable mild taste. A fine bitter.
On tap. Dark golden with a small white head. Fruity and hoppy notes. Fruit, malt anf bitter tastet. Medium body with a nice, bitter finish.
This is probably my favourite pint.  Studying in London, this was on tap at a pub across the street from my Department which was where my PhD Supervisor hid out.

Cask, 7 stars, Thornton Hough. My first UK outdoor pint of 2008! Dark amber colour with a medium lingering white head. Some lacing. Dense hoppy aroma, flavour is more of the same with a nice grassy undercurrent and a tasty bitter finish.

Cask - Rose & Crown, Canterbury. A handsome bronzed orange colour with an off-white head. Distinctly crisp floral and resiny aromas. The floral notes of the hops are rather pronounced in the flavour too with a clear malty undertone to back it up. Very pleasant resiny hop finish and a clean palate and soft medium bodied palate.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2008 Cask at Guildford Arms, Edinburgh. Dark golden color with a white head. Aroma: Lots of citrus, grapefruit, butter and some sweet malt. Flavor: Hoppy, citruslike bitterness, grape, lemon, butter, honey, spicy and some bready/grainy malt. Very crisp and fresh.

Cask at pub The Chequers at High Street in Oxford (nice place - great pies). Orangey amber. Floral, raisin, bitter aroma. Soft and crisp flavoru - lots of everything - hops, malt, intensivity. Best britisk ale ever - for me. Tasted though in lovely company with my wife, a few hours before visiting The Fat Duck in Bray - full of joyfull anticipation - could perhaps distract my views?

Coppery colored, little yellow head. Sweet, slightly hopped aroma with lots of lemon, not too original one. Medium bodied. Flavor is more floral with still sweet lemon and fruits, aftertaste is still rather round with lemon. Basic cask.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2009 Landlord with its balanced hoppiness and wonderful mouthfeel is a really rather special drink.  Hoppy aroma, oranges and resin, sometimes a hint of sulphur, caramelly malt.  Full mouthfeel, initial malt sweetness and attacking hops, rounded and balanced, hops are prominent - there is no lag in flavour, no poor part of the palate.  Lovely balanced bitter finish, malt and hops fight for attention, hops arent going anywhere.  Lovely spicy, sitrus overtones come and go.  Dont want it through a sparkler, I like the natural caress.  Needs a few weeks age in cellar.  Hugely complex, what a yeast.
Cask at Brigantes Bar, York. Very nice amber colour, hoppy aroma and balanced flavour with some sweet malt and lots of hop bitterness. Better than the bottled version, I thought.

Cask in Market Drayton, forget the pub.  Pours a hazy copper with a medium white head.  Aroma is strong citrus Fuggles and Goldings and some malt.  Overly dominated by grapefruit hops, with some grainy malt to back it up.  A bit oily.  Acidic finish.

Cask @ Brigantes, november 07. Shinny golden color with a medium white head (sparkler). Shinny malty aroma with some tea/englsih hop aroma. Pale malt flavor with some citric notes, salty ending and dryness at the end. Medium to light mouthfeel, malty, starts hoppy with a nice dryness and mineral end. Nice, spicy hops aftertaste. Nice, tea, spicy golden bitter.
[704-20070926] Cask @ The Old Shades (London, GL). Light citrus fruity aroma notes, some hops. Clear, orange brown body with a quick foamy white head. More grapefruit citrus hops in the flavour.

A really nice balance between creaminess and sharpness. Best sampled in its heartlands of West and North Yorkshire. Long and proud tradition of being recognised as one of the best brews in the whole of the country.

Cask at Hornimen at Hays in London. Pours amber golden with a white head. Medium bodied, but with a light texturet that is not watery. Nice aroma of sweet british toffee malts with a touch of hops. Initial flavor of toffee and butterscotch that is nicely balanced by herbal hops and a wisp of fruity esters. Yeasty and earthy finish. The best bitter that I had on this visit to London.

Cask at the Brown Cow, Bingley, 19-05-06 Its good to have a beer in its heartland, somehow it just gives it the little something extra its like playing at home in football I suppose. Poured amber coloured and with a nice hint of malt and hops on the nose. A class bitter in every way and its no suprise that its won so many accocolades it just tastes great when on form and can easily send many johnny come latelies scuttling, lovely fresh fruity beer that ticks all the right boxes.

Cask at 3 Greyhounds.  Rich golden aroma, very nice orange marmalade and light spiciness.  Flavour shows excellent balance with notable grainy/earthy UK malts set against fresh spicy hops.  Its getting harder and harder to differentiate among these middle strength UK bitters... Im not sure how the Brits do it.  FWIW, this one is excellent.

cask @ The Old Bakery (Kenilworth), The Clarendon Arms (Kenilworth), and The Wenlock Arms. It was very interesting for me to taste this beer in various conditions, but Ill just rate at its best (which happened to be at the Wenlock). Light amber in colour with aromatic notes of pear, caramel, and both herbal and earthy hops. Bready and caramel malts in the mouth, along with sone dark spice, earth, and a bit of grassy hop. Well balanced indeed. A classic.

Nose of malt and hops with a creaminess associated with an ESB. Pours a copper beer with a full white head. Taste is malty with toffee sweetness balanced with some really nice hops. A great British beer.
Pours amber with off-white head. Aroma is hoppy / citrus / sulphur. Taste is earthy / caramel / slightly metallic although pretty drinkable.

Comments: Headless, but very tight beer, mineral, firmly bitter, refreshing acid and dry. Excellent.

Cask.  At The Duke of Wellington on The Strand, Covent Garden, London.  Clear, pale amber, with an average off-white head.  Slightly pungent, funky herbal hop aroma backed by grainy-wheaty malt.  The taste is low-level bitter herbal hops, slightly acidic, with a long grainy finish.  The bodys nice and chewy, solid astringency, very soft yet complex mouthfeel.  Excellent - much more interesting than many bitters, I loved that acidity.
(Cask at Tennents Bar, Glasgow, the day after RBESG 2007) Golden color, small head. Quite weak aroma. Hoppy, grassy flavor with some fruits.

Dark amber colour with mediumsized white head. Aroma is fruity, hoppy, earthy and slightly caramelly. Flavour is hoppy, fruity, quite grassy and caramelly. Pleasant one.

Cask conditioned at Tennents Bar, Glasgow. 
Clear golden colour. Bit eggy and light sweet malty with good flavouring hops and medium bitterness.

Cask at The Priory Arms, Stockwell. In appearance, aroma and flavour, very much a classic bitter - simple, balanced beer. A bit of woodiness to the flavour but this didnt taste like a beer thats been supreme British champion four times. Looking down the comments, it seems that it can vary from average to sublime - I must have caught it at the former.
Cask at the Stanley Arms in Aughton. I cant remember ever having a bad pint of this beer Pours clear and golden, crisp taste in the mouth, hoppy with hints of citrus.

Cask at Hales Pub, Harrogate. Pours a great-looking clear gold with an average size mostly-lasting creamy white head. Nice lacing on the glass. Mild aroma of sweet malt, fruit and hops. Slightly mild but tasty flavour of sweet malt, fruit and hops with a decent bitter finish. Medium bodied, creamy mouthfeel. Great stuff, an excellent session Bitter!

Draught at various pubs in London. A fully golden brown beer with a whitish head. The nose is of hops and caramel. Rather earthy with some sulphur. The taste is mainly of marmite. Earthy. The mouthfeel wasn t impressive at all. The beer left a beautiful lacing. Decently hoppy with a bitter finish. This bitter lacks in power.

Cask (Gallows Bird, Espoo, Real Ale Festival 2007).
Ginger and citrus in perfect balance. Very long lasting hoppy bitter aftertaste, which is most welcome.
Light amber, light spicy hop, smooth light malt with a light spicy bitter linger , very juicy.

[CASK: The Metropolitan, West Didsbury, Manchester 04/08/06] A very pleasing taste, quite light and sweet. Pale and easy drinking. Citrus taste makes it undistandable why its Marilyn Monroes favorie pints.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2011 Cask conditioned at the Victoria, Clifton Lido, Bristol 15/4/07. This pint was served in an excellent state of quality, hence the rating. Golden with thin, lacy head. Plenty of hops and elderflowers in the aroma. Excellent bitter flavour with a hint of biscuity malt in the finish. One of the UKs best and far better than the bottled version [4.0]. Re-rate 2011 at the Mall, Clifton, Bristol. Far sweeter than I remembered, with some toffee notes and less crisp malts, Nothing special [3.2]

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2008 cask @ the blue eye maid, se1. Gold with thin white head. Thick lace. Fruity hop aroma. Taste of hops, lemongrass, oak and malts with hints of fruit. Long bitter finish of lemon rind with light spice. (5,3, 7, 3, 14)
Re-Rate from The Water Poet, Spitalfields. 
Ive heard this is one of those beers thats easy to come by but not always in the best condition. I have to consider myself lucky as Ive had several good uns.
Opaque gold with a thin white head. Nose of tropical fruits, hops, orange and malt in the distance. Fresh grassy hops, much like lemongrass, balanced with a nice well rounded malt edge and a dry finish. Went down a treat.

A Mes rate: 
Gravicask @ Planet Thanet. So often average but wow when it is on song it is superb. Lovely dark golden colour with a creamy head. Looks like you would image the perfect bitter to look. Aroma is perfect mellow hops with some very slight sweetness just giving it a bit of an edge and it is capped off with beautiful notes of almond and marzipan. All the above comes through in the flavour too but it comes with some lovely citric lemon and grapefruit notes and some more sugar and cream. Amazing vanillary hit with a gradually bittering and lengthy hoppy finish. Palate is spot on. Great beer. It must be said what a great festival too...

At The Black Friar. Light citrus aroma. Amber gold color with a temporary white head that laced. Fresh fruity taste backed by citrus. There is malt, and though there is a light balance of hop in the finish, there seems a bit more malt than hop there.

On tap at The Horniman at Hays, A nice and full chewy body with a light and refresing balance of hops and malts. Nice and smooth going down with a likeable bitter aftertaste. It went very nicely with my shepards pie.

Cask at Crown Inn, Southampton.  Bronze colur. Intense flowery, resiny hop aroma. Dry and soft, yet crisp with very evident hay-like hop flavour and a nice chewy malt character. Feels like barley juice. A lovely bitter with striking late bitterness.

Golden beer with a light head.  The aroma is lightly caramel and hopped and the flavour is dry, caramel and creamy.  Overall a nice dry caramel beer.

Cask,  Fox Inn, Lutterworth.  Golden with a small head.  Aromas are shredded marmalade with sweet malts and light hopping.  Flavours are sweet, stickly marmalade with some buttery malts.  Very nice sweet hops with a dry finish.

Orangy amber, small head which quickly goes, not much lacing. Has a rough bitter flavour, understated hops, and a sweet after taste. I found it a bit to cloying for my palate, but overall a decent pint.
Cask @ Real Ale Festival, Gallows Bird, Espoo. Light orange colour, small white head. Not much aroma.... nice apple, herb taste. Good, average thickness.

On cask in cloisters, Edinburgh. Excellent light amber session bitter. Perfumy, floral Golding hop aroma. Clean, fairly dry, slight caramilisation and good hop flavour. Finishes with a clean bitterness. Overall one of the best session bitters around.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2007 At the Charles XII, Heslington. Golden-orange brew with a nice lasting head, little lace. Some caramel in the aroma but more pronounced hop citrus, even more pronounced grassy notes.  Taste was much the same, with flowery notes and grass predominate, some caramel malt in the background.  Easy drinker, fairly carbonated.

Re-rate: Need to bump this one up a couple notches as Ive been drinking it more regularly.  Very much on par with the best bitters Ive had so far.  More pronounced citrus in the taste than I had first experienced.
Frankly, not as good as it used to be. Had it in a number of pubs over the last few months and noted that it doesnt seem to have the depth of taste and character that it once did.

On cask at the Old Coach and Horse, Harbledown near Canterbury.
First had a pint of this when I studied up in Darlington. Almost 15 years has past since then but my face lit up when I saw this guest ale.   
Soft fruit (faint citrus) and a grassy, refeshing hop twang. This is the kind of quality session bitter that I miss so much now Ive moved away from England.
This is a wonderful bitter, great session brew but more than that. Its a golden tangerine studded with intricately cut diamonds. Without doubt this can walk the tightrope.
Cask in London. Small head, pale brown beer. Some malt, but dominated by grassy hops. Nice.

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2008 Thin white head over lightish orange body. Light tea aroma. Light, sweetish delicate tea and citric hops taste with faint, dryish, smoky aftertaste. Nice session beer. (0.5pt on cask. Should rerate.)

1/2 pint cask, Berts Bar, Edinburgh. Darkish golden colour. Throws a really fine-laced creamy white head. Aroma seems to indicate that the beer is somewhat off. Slight sulphur. Flavour-wise it feels quite alright. Refreshingly bitter when it enters the mouth. Minty drying grassy hops. Nice mouthfeel with some crispness, which a lot of other cask ales seems to be missing. I dont think it is neccessarily the carbonation, but just as much the bitterness and the livelyness of the beer. Without it the beer can just feel too flat and uninteresting. Head clings to the glass.

Draught at the Peacock, Nottingham. Orange with a lasting white head leaving good lacing, a strong complex hop flavour and an intense long-lasting, and extremely pleasant bitter aftertaste. Everything a bitter should be.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2006 Ah. Much more like it. Reeks of eggy sulphur and leafy hop, like a classic English Bitter should. A vastly more balanced combination of floral hops, bready malt, honeyish sweetness and zesty grapefruit bitterness than the bottled version. The parting bitterness is way more rounded and integrated into the overall flavour of the beer. One of the very finest English pints. Sneaky 10min lunchtime tipple at The Fox.

Pint served in excellent condition and at perfect room temperature before I had a full English breakfast at the Fox and Anchor in Smithfield (15.09.2006). The ale turned out to be my best on cask during a fortnights holiday in England. Golden brown in colour with a thin, but lasting foamy layer. Delicious fresh, fruity and flowery to the nose. Brilliant bitterness that lingers all the way through. Hints of caramel sweetness. Very good, indeed.

Cask in London. Small head and pale amber colour. Malty aroma with peppery feel and a flowery hoppyness. Extremely dry mouthfeel with tones of berries and caramel. The bitterness is not harsh but flowery.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2006 My first real ale in britain.  I had know idea that I was starting with the best bitter I could probably get my hands on.  Aroma is a bit weird from the yeast.  Its actually the worst part of the beer, but the flavor is so absolultly splendid.  It comes from the hand pump a lovely copperish orange with a nice half inch of head.  The flavor is full of terrific fresh hops, creating piney and citrus notes.  Plenty of bittering to this one, but still very nicely balanced.  palate is just right for bitter.  This is an amazing beer.  You must have one if you are in England.
Good head and a strong dark colour. Well-balanced flavour with a good hoppy finish

Handpump @ the Minster Tavern, Ely (A town built around religion and beer - whilst the latter is enticing the former does nothing for me, but the view of that hauntingly beautiful and majestic cathedral from the front window of this pub is awe-inspiring and almost unimaginable.), Cambridgeshire. 
Anyway, back to the beer. Bright orange gold with a soapy, messed up head that lasted and daubed froth down the glass. Distant aroma of orange juice and caramel. Fruity and floral in the mouth with a nice ripe spicy kick. Base malts and bready yeast sit below layers of apricot, peach and tangerine-like esters which make it tangy and fresh. Finish is quite short after a mild bitter bite on the swallow, but it is clean and light. I quite liked this one, as I knew I would. An even-levelled, balanced quaffer.
Too much H2S and lack of clarity ruin the initial impressions of this beer. Very dry almost to the point of being harsh. Not easy to drink and not enjoyable

Cask, handpump @ ...... . Dark golden with small creamy head. Fruity hops, tropical fruits, toasted-bread and light caramel in the aroma. Very fruity and strong hop flavor. Finishes fruity-bitter with some caramel and toasted bread notes.

Cask @ the Harp, Covent Garden, London. Slightly hazy golden/reddish colour with a small off-white head. Fruity slightly floral aroma. Fruity hoppy flavor, with some malty hints. Fruity hoppy aftertaste.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2006 Re-rate: Cask at The Hewlet in Cheltenham. This was in better shape than the last time I tried it. Same nice looking pour and lingering malt warmth as last time, but without the touch of sulfur, which is a rather big improvement. Rating 4 Aug 2006: Warm copper with a fine, sticky beige head. Lots of fruity esters, Apples that have been in the sun just a little long. A touch of sulfur. A little dill. Really nice soft toasty grain malt. An authentic tasting expression of the field, like crunching a few kernels of a good barley malt. Good balanced underlying hops. Lively apple/pear estery quality. A little lingering hops. Soft mouthfeel, cool, but still lively. If this was a little cleaner, it would be an impressive bitter. Good enough that it merits seeking a re-rate, should the opportunity present itself.

Cask (@ Westend, Stratford upon Avon): Light amber coloured, pretty small lacing head; strong fruity, strong aromatic herbal bitter nose with a sweet-malty touch; moderate sweet-bitter lavour; heavy and lingering aromatic-bitter finish. Well rounded, extremely well quaffable......................

Darkish amber color, small off-white head. Crisp and same time papery malty nose mixed with dried fruits. Fruity (dried fruits), bitterish, sort of strong lager feeling here. Balanced and drinkable but uninspiring.
A pint at the Forth in Newcastle-upon-Tyne, UK.  Thick white head.  Golden-reddish color.  Super bitter ending.  All right beer.
Goldend brown body with a light white head.  Some pine and hops evident in the aroma.  Sweet yeast taste with some light hops.  Bitter ending.
Amber golden body. Smoother and more body than what I remember of the bottled version. Hops but not showing till late.
Amber with a decent-sized foamy head.  A flowery, hoppy scent with sweet aromas of fruit, caramel and a touch of honey.  Thick and silky on the palate.

Cask at the Pontefact Castle in London, #5 on the 2006 Europe tour-Light amber color with slight hoppy aroma and taste.  Some fruit taste and aroma was there too.  The finish was thin.  Im surprised by the high ratings, maybe it because it was the laste brew of a long day.
Cask at Dog & Duck London W1 26 Apr 06. Bright golden. A small white head. Fruity aroma. Develops into  a pleasant bitter aftertaste. Well balanced. A marvellous beer.

Cask at Black Friar, London. Dark golden with small creamy head. Fruity hops, tropical fruits, toasted-bread and light caramel in the aroma. Very fruity and strong hop flavor, still very balaced.
